Component Methodologies

Solar (SWdown/So):
Solar (SWdown/So): S o l a r
( S W d o w n / S o ) :

• One of the (under-utilized) success stories of satellite meteorology
• One of the (under-utilized) success stories of satellite meteorology

• Many “snapshots” (hourly) results from geostationary platforms, time-integrated
• Many “snapshots” (hourly) results from geostationary platforms, time-integrated

• Simple atmospheric physical model with measured surface albedo used for
• Simple atmospheric physical model with measured surface albedo used for

cloud detection, quantifying cloud albedo, radiative transfer effects in clear and cloudy atmospheres
cloud detection, quantifying cloud albedo, radiative transfer effects in clear and
cloudy atmospheres

• Several methods using GOES/Meteosat/GMS data by independent investigators
• Several methods using GOES/Meteosat/GMS data by independent investigators

• Daily So usually with < 10% error versus pyranometers

• Takes into account angular dependence of Tb on view angle using “two-source” model

thermal data as twice-daily input.

250 m resolution MODIS

imagery when available.

Verification of soil moisture products can be very difficult :
Verification of soil moisture products can be very difficult :

• Lack of large observational soil moisture networks
• Lack of large observational soil moisture networks

• Problems verifying a point observation with a 10km x 10km pixel (ALEXI)
• Problems verifying a point observation with a 10km x 10km pixel (ALEXI)

• Have chosen to verify ALEXI through time series correlations using spatially averaged `

• Assume that ALEXI’s total system evapotranspiration is an integrated average of available water within the 0-200 cm soil column. Unfortunately, we know very little about the distribution of available water within that 0-200 cm soil column.
• Assume that ALEXI’s total system evapotranspiration is an integrated average of available water

• Using the available water profile from NAM/EDAS initialization fields as a first guess of the soil profile, and adjust this profile to fit the integrated average of available water from ALEXI.

Current mesoscale numerical models use sophisticated land-surface models to handle the coupling between the surface and the atmosphere.
Current mesoscale numerical models use
sophisticated land-surface models to handle
the coupling between the surface and the
atmosphere.

The NOAH-LSM uses a 4-layer soil moisture model to handle the exchange of soil water between the surface, sub-surface and atmosphere.
The NOAH-LSM uses a 4-layer soil moisture
model to handle the exchange of soil water
between the surface, sub-surface and
atmosphere.

Under high vegetative cover, ALEXI loses some sensitivity to handle the surface layer (0-10 cm), and under low vegetative cover, ALEXI loses some sensitivity to the sub-surface layers (10- 200 cm).
Under high vegetative cover, ALEXI loses some
sensitivity to handle the surface layer (0-10 cm),
and under low vegetative cover, ALEXI loses
some sensitivity to the sub-surface layers (10-
200 cm).

We assume that a fraction of evapotranspiration is directly (1:1) related to a fraction of available water, which in turn can be used to calculate a volumetric soil moisture, given values of field capacity and permanent wilting point for the soil type.
We assume that a fraction of evapotranspiration
is directly (1:1) related to a fraction of available
water, which in turn can be used to calculate a
volumetric soil moisture, given values of field
capacity and permanent wilting point for the soil
type.
